comments.commentBody:
Thank you for the link, David. The article is excellent and well worth reading.

A personal side note: I met Brooksley Born when I was a young professional in Washington, D.C. many years ago. At the time, Ms. Born was a highly-regarded partner at the law firm of Arnold and Porter, and I was neither prominent nor powerful. I was surprised and tremendously impressed by Ms. Born's genuine warmth and generosity. She was the antithesis of the difficult or strident person that she was portrayed as by those who disagreed with her on derivatives policy.

I am a fan of Brooksley Born.
Thanks Anetliner for the personal tidbit about Brooksley Born. I saw the pbs frontline documentary about her and the battles with summer and them.

More about Brooksly Born and Summers.
http://alumni.stanford.edu/get/page/magazine/article/?article_id=30885
The whole article is well worth reading.

"Clinton named her to head the CFTC in 1996. She was not without experience: at Arnold & Porter she had represented the London Futures Exchange in rule making and other matters before the commodities agency.

She also knew how markets could be manipulated, having represented a major Swiss bank in litigation stemming from an attempt by the Hunt family of Dallas to corner the silver market in the 1980s.

“Brooksley had the advantage of knowing the law and understanding the fragility of the system if it weren’t regulated,” says Michael Greenberger, her former adviser at the CFTC. “She could see that the data points, by lack of regulation, were heading the country into a serious set of calamities, each calamity worse than the one before.”

Under a Republican predecessor, the CFTC had in 1993 largely exempted from regulation more exotic derivatives that involved just two parties. The thinking was that sophisticated entities negotiating individually tailored derivatives could look out for themselves. More generic derivatives still had to be traded on exchanges, which were subject to regulation."

'
That's the most normal one yet.

I fear none of those things. Israel already struck Syria itself. No response. Anyway, Israel is perfectly capable of defending itself with all the military aid we've given.

Iran knows that half of America eagerly looks forward to a war with him. He's not going to risk it for a few of Assad's chemical weapons.

The real risk is giving the green light to WMD use. That's what really scares me, because the results are so unknowable.

keep on fearing Iran, a country that to date has never attacked another country. Keep on fearing Hamas and Hizbollah for their home made fire crackers that leave a hole in the ground a size of a football, and in the case of the latter, katyusha rockets of the bygone days.

Never fear US that has been bombing Af-Pak, Yemen, Iraq, Somalia, at will. No worries here. Never fear Israel, which has already bombed Syria four times in the last two years, has bombed Palestinians with impunity (under the pretext of those home made fire crackers that to date have injured 3 people). Those are only Muslims and Arabs after all.

The mission creep I fear is what we do when Iran joins the war in Syria, even more than it has already.  What do we do when Iran's proxy Hezbollah launches rockets at northern Israel?  When its other proxy Hamas launches rockets at Israel's coastal plain?  When bombs start going off in foreign capitals that otherwise have nothing to do with Syria?  War never plays by the rules we assume were in place when we first went in.

[shouts out character's name]

I'll count the number of connections to the puzzle when I can stand to look at the grid again.

Obama has been working very hard indeed to build support for punishing Assad, both domestically and internationally. That is entirely inconsistent with your "gut feeling".

Sorry for making this personal, but my gut feeling is that you haven't really liked Obama from the start, and are looking around for some reason to not give him credit for trying to do the right thing.

And you are certainly not alone in that. Look at all the Republican "hawks" who are voting against this strike, even though they were much bigger backers for a much bigger war based on much weaker evidence: Iraq.

My gut feeling is that Obama does not really want to take any military action in Syria. In fact, I would even venture to say that he does not really care that much about what is happening in Syria - sort of like saying 'let them fight it out among themselves; one or the other or both sides will lose and no one will be worse off'

The ONLY reason he feels he has to hit Syria is to keep Israel from attacking Iran unilaterally, which will start a much bigger conflagration. He wants to be able to say, 'look, you can trust me when I say I will take action if and when they cross (your) red line; I did it in Syria' - and keep hoping and praying that that will never happen - at least, not on his watch.
So you're comfortable with giving Putin a veto over policing war crimes?
Strange that so few people in leadership have experience in war since we've been in one or another for quite a while.

I'm embarrassed. Chagrined, disappointed, and now outraged by our government's unstinting resolve to light up the Syrian desert with cruise missiles DESPITE 80% of American's disapproval.

The amateur attempt by the Obama administration to craft a plan that makes strategic sense drew a smirk from Vlad Putin and the rest of the G-20. We're a laughingstock with nukes.

None on the White House staff has any experience in war. The path our president and his closest advisers have taken violates every principle of war, starting with the element of surprise. Nobody in his or her right mind believes we have anything like a clearly defined and obtainable objective. Heaven help us from ourselves!

We have no plans to "take them out." We have been very clear about that, for good reasons.

First, bombing chemical weapons stores would release chemical gas in large amounts. That is what we say we don't want to do, or see done.

Second, whatever is not destroyed would have its security wrecked. We also say we want them kept secured.

Third, and more delicate, these are strategic deterrent weapons. That is why the Soviets supplied them and the factories and systems for them back in the 1970's, and they have been kept on that basis since. That is why Syria did not join the Treaty, which in turn is why Israel didn't join.

The normal rule when strategic deterrent weapons are threatened goes by the phrase "use them or lose them." It is part of deterrence theory, as applied by everyone, the US, the Russians, the Chinese, the Israelis, everyone.

There is a significant risk some would be fired, because that is what everyone else says they would do under like circumstances. Guess who they'd be fired at? Guess what happens next. That is the nightmare of Mutual Assured Deterrence, and the whole idea is NOT to make that first attack. We know better than to do that.

So no, for three very good reasons, we are not going to take out those chemical weapons, no matter what else we do. We have made very clear public statements to that effect, as deterrence theory requires we should.
Obama has made it clear repeatedly that has heard and considered your opinions.  It seems to me you are the one not willing to listen or consider that you might be wrong.
In order to make sense of CRONYISM you've got to realize that the word "partial" is misdirection.  It means "favorable to" rather than "incomplete."

I appreciate it Kiki.

When I can stand to look at the grid again, I'll see if that makes sense to me now.

One strike away from a perfect game and Petit blows it.  My condolences Martin, that's been the way of the Giants this season.  At least they won 3-0.  San Diego pulled one out in the bottom of the ninth 4-3 to keep the Giants in the cellar.

There's a fine baseball game going on between the SF Giants and the Arizona Diamondbacks.

MINIMAL number of baserunners on one side, through 8 innings.

Mr. Peterson,

How is the context of Larry Summers mistakes a defense of him?

It's just the opposite. He's an intellectual bully and his ability to get his way even when he's dead wrong is the key reason that Obama should NOT appoint him to anything ever again.

I am happy that someone else remembers Mr. Bush's "Ownership Society."

How did that work out for US?

I am not sure Summers necessarily thought that. I'd say both the Clinton and Bush administrations were equally bad in their own ways. The Wall Street Journal editorial page keeps pointing out that banks were allegedly "forced" into making risky loans to minorities, supposedly because "predatory lending" -- which used to be something minorities objected to -- suddenly turned into something that minorities were "victimized" by the lack of.

I do wonder if minority advocates were not paid off by bank CEO's who wanted to make a killing off of a high volume of loans, and didn't care if it hurt the shareholders in the long run. One should look at how much the financial sector donated to Pres. Clinton, who was overseeing the various departments that suddenly clamored for banks to make bad loans to minorities which ultimately destroyed their lives, may have hurt bank shareholders, but certainly did allow then bank CEO's and various employees to rake in a bunch of cash, before moving onto possibly bigger and better things.

One should never allow blind partisanship to prevent one from objecting to greed and hypocrisy, on both sides of the aisle. Nor should be allow both sides to play tennis with the poor -- batting them back and forth like nothing but tennis balls. First the right victimizes them in one way, leaving them vulnerable to being victimized by the left. People turning a blind eye to their favored side of the aisle doing wrong makes this happen. It's about time that stops.

I agree that the financial deregulation that took place on Lawrence Summers' watch was a mistake, and if anything,even back in '98, more regulation was needed, not less. But in partial defense, Summers probably quite reasonably assumed the next Administration, which turned out to be the Bush Administration, would have basic competence, adequate staffing in Treasury and SEC, and not push their own regulators to turn a blind eye. In fact,G. W. Bush's "Ownership Society"  ploy during his reelection campaign was another motive for the Bush Administration to turn a blind eye to excesses, and probably even "winkwink" at the excesses.

Nothing can go wrong... go wrong... go wrong... One exchange wanted updates on the latest trades, and did not receive an immediate answer. As a result, the exchange repeatedly requested an update, and then began sending an error message in the form of a zero-dollar trade. Each of these actions requires a number of events to happen, which begin long chains of code.

All of this happened in a matter of seconds, which makes human response impossible. The amount of data being transferred between exchanges has multiplied drastically in the last few years, and the infrastructure may not be able to handle irregularities when they occur. A delay of a few tenths of a second can result in thousands and thousands of orders not being processed in the required window of time.

The benefits of High Frequency Trading are looking smaller and smaller.
This one is definitely a good Educational post. I agree with each and every a conclusion made on this topic. It is really very educational. Thanks for discussing. It is going to help me a lot.

@Thomas Zaslavsky:

Re: "You are correct, but what you call "the left" is really the middle;"

Very true. President Obama has exacerbated the problem of the pundits and pols characterizing policies supported by the vast majority of the public as "leftist". He has done this in many, many ways. He has attempted to establish his "centrist cred" by attacking the left. But by attacking the left so virulently, he has not simply portrayed himself to their "right", but rather has marginalized, and undermined these centrist positions - thus leaving him no respected, credible, and legitimate "leftist position", to use as a counterbalance to prove himself centrist. This has the effect of moving the perceived "center" ever rightward.

President Obama is not alone in moving what is considered among the pundit and pol "VSP's" as "centrist" ever rightward, but he has a position with great power to inform discussion, and move public opinion, and he has used it very poorly.

Given that the President is extremely smart, it is only logical to assume that this is not an accident, and that his true policy desires are aligned with his policy proposals. For example, he truly believes cutting SS via chained CPI is good policy, even though 80% of the nation disagrees, and would rather raise FICA taxes than cut SS. Similarly, on drones, surveillance, trade agreements which serve to cut wages - he is *for* all these things - not just conceding.

You've put your finger on the problem with the entire Obama presidency. We needed an FDR to show the public which party was on their side. Instead, we got someone who, only a few years ago, would have been considered a moderate Republican.

The only representation liberalism has had in government in recent years is as a whipping boy for the right, which claims, with mind-boggling dishonesty, that Obama is the most liberal president in history (when it isn't claiming, in an even more laughable lie, that he's a socialist).

There was a NY Times magazine article that said Obama wanted to reduce poverty when he was a Chicago community organizer. So he got into politics, where the power is. The sad thing is, as he gained power, he lost focus on or the ability to really do something about it (beyond traditional government handouts which has certainly helped millions).

Why is this? Why is someone who saw, first-hand, the effects of inner-city poverty, who was a grassroots organizer, who vowed to alleviate poverty by going in to politics - yet when he ascended to the most powerful position in the world, was powerless to push for the kinds of changes he wanted 25 years ago?

Without question, Republican opposition gets much of the credit (or blame) for trying to derail Obama's very moderate, centrist agenda. Also, our highly partisan Congress probably couldn't agree on a bathroom code if they had to.

But we must also look at the man himself. Obama is not a fighter, in the mold of Teddy Roosevelt or FDR or LBJ. As groundbreaking as his election was, as hopeful as those of us on the left were (and the middle), he's disappointed us in significant areas - the debt ceiling, the jobs bill, Wall Street regulation. Many people want Hillary Clinton to become another groundbreaking President, but unless she can be the fighter Obama isn't, we'd be better off with someone who is.

When the left adopts half-measures that don't solve the problems, the people eventually give up on them.  (See Australia's recent election.)  Then we end up with right wing disasters.  While Janet Yellen is hardly a leftist, a Clinton retread like Summers is the last thing the country needs.
Rest assured there will be More To Follow.
I just caught up with yesterday's comments and that long MTF thread to the Blog's first comment.  I see things went to pot right off the bat.

@History Prof and MJ:
It's not quite that simple. The home federation controls the sale of the television rights, and beIn Sports,a subsidiary of Al Jazeera, swooped in to buy the away USMNT matches and caught E$PN unawares. E$PN *responded* by buying up the US broadcast rights to the Mexican away matches, which caught beIn either unawares or indifferent, and they also have a relationship with the FMF, as both USSF and FMF use the same PR firm, so they bought the games at Mexico, too, on the (correct) thought that American fans would prefer to watch El Tri rather than nothing on FIFA match days. They further did a good service by avoiding their usual roster of British broadcasters for those matches (Derek Rae, Adrian Healy, and have relegated Robbie Mustoe to studio "analysis"), and instead have a work in progress with Fernando Palomo on play by play and former Venezuelan International Alejandro Moreno on analysis. They're really not bad, especially considering that English is not their first language (but doesn't appear to be for Gus Johnson on Fox, either). And they're not holding back in their criticism of Mexico, who are in desperate need for a win (or at least a draw) in Columbus, and have *their* midfield general, Gerardo Torrado, similarly suspended for Tuesday. That Mexico scored in the fist 6 minutes and never again, despite dominating the first half hour, shows that they are desperately vulnerable, and will have to rally just to make the playoff w/ New Zealand.
@MJ There are obviously more fans of Mexican soccer on the US than fans of the US team.

Poor lineup. Too bad about Bradley. Why wasn't Beckerman introduced into the game? Altidore's yellow card so foolish.

Can the U.S. beat Mexico? Who knows.
The US team looked very amateurish,  I hope this ends the "snow bowl" squabble   Why Klinsmann is sticking with Donovan in games which count towards classification to the WC is a mystery to me.

Klinsmann looked more bewildered spectator than confident coach tonight. Too slow to react to what was obviously not working. Beckerman or Diskerud would have been a better option than Cameron to fill the Bradley slot. And perhaps there is a silver lining behind the cloud of Altidore's idiotic foul. Maybe Johansson will get some serious playing time. I don't know why JFK even bothered to put him in tonight. And boy, don't we miss Cherundolo?

sad, but not an unexpected loss, imo. costa rico is still very tough at home, even outside of saprissa, and the usa seemed off-kilter coming in, with altidore having a knock, clint not yet settled in, and donovan trying to fit back in.

relatedly, but kinda not, i miss being able to watch soccer after canceling my tv subscription (was watching too much crap). in this day and age, it should be possible to purchase games a la carte off the web. luddites!!! :p

That was offensively bad...

Run DMB should not be in the game, he's a dead end. Seems like all he can do is make runs, no facility with the ball. His go to move is pass it backwards.

Orozco should not have been in the game, he's a sieve

Our midfield game was completely absent without Bradley. Really shameful how we were reduced to hopeful long balls.

Dempsey did not do particularly well. Seemed like his touch deserted him. He had a good strike that was saved. But overall wasn't impressive.

Altidore is an idiot for that bump to get a yellow card. I can't actually believe he was that stupid.

Besler needs a remedial class in tactical fouls. He never should have allowed that goal.

I think Klinnsman deserves quite a bit of the blame. I hated the starting lineup. I hated the subs. EJ instead of Altidore? The US never appeared to have a coherent game plan. And now we're going to be missing 3 for Mexico.

Speaking of Mexico. I guess I should be happy we're not them.
Summers has had his chance. He needs to ride off into the sunset and never be heard from again.

I have and will continue to make my opposition to Summers known both with the white house & congress. That being said I don't believe for a moment that Obama will listen or heed the many voices objecting to placing Larry Summers in a position of power to serve his wall street cronies. President Obama has a now long history of telling us one thing then doing just what he intended in the first place. No where is this more evident then in national security and the financial crisis. Blame the obstructionist in congress all you want but even in those things he has the most influence Obama has never not failed to disappoint.

Sorry for the original numbers.

I concur entirely with Dr. Stiglitz's analysis and strongly urge the appointment of Janet Yellen as Fed chair. I agree that Dr. Yellen is the superior candidate with respect to forecasting ability, monetary policy leadership, management track record and temperament.

Dr. Summers would be miscast as Fed chair, but would likely excel in other important roles. The U.S. badly needs a new infrastructure investment policy, and Dr. Summers has been a strong advocate in this arena. I would be happy to support Dr. Summers as Infrastructure Czar, a post that would benefit from his advocacy skills and fiscal policy expertise.

In addition to commenting on Dr. Stiglitz's column, NYT commenters might also want to contact the White House with their views:
http://www.whitehouse.gov
202-465-1111 (comments)
202-465-1414 (switchboard)
I live in Florida and when I see the obesity in my vegetarian friends I want no part of not eating meat. My only skinny friends are the ones who religiously follow the Atkins diet.

I'm not a pork eater. I live in Nashville and see the size of the people that eat pork and I want NO part of that. That said, pork is an inexpensive source of protein and there are a lot of lower income people in the U.S. for whom pork is a staple of their diet.

When the largest pork producer in a country of 300 million people gets sold to a company based in a nation of 1.4 BILLION people, I can expect that a huge percentage of the product produced will get exported to that country.

Any business wants to be the dominant producer/provider in the largest market available to the company's products. The largest market has the best potential for growth, market share, profit and prestige.

The Chinese hold US produced products in very high regard, and they are willing to pay a premium for products produced in America.

A significant percentage of Smithfield's annual production will now be exported to satisfy the ever expanding Chinese market.

So...the dominant pork producer will now try to become the dominant producer in a country with a population 4 times the size of the U.S..

As Smithfield concentrates on becoming the dominant pork exporter/producer for the Chinese market there will be less pork available for U.S. consumption.

The law of supply and demand tells us that if this deal goes through, pork prices in the U.S. will rise dramatically, and Smithfield will be the main beneficiary in both countries. U.S. consumers will be the losers in this equation.

KILL THIS DEAL !
